items.title: Schools of Design Extend Their Reach Into Asia
items.abstract: While the potential for growth is huge, given Asia’s rising creative industries, the logistics of opening American art and design schools can be complicated.
keywords: Savannah College of Art and Design

items.title: Nashville’s Latest Big Hit Could Be the City Itself
items.abstract: The city, which sat on the sidelines while its Southern sisters boomed, has found itself in the national spotlight, with economic gains and a newly found popularity.

items.title: ‘Mexsicko City’ Turns a Corner in Its Clean Air Marathon
items.abstract: Even amid other environmental gains, it is the improvement in air quality that has most burnished the city’s green credentials.

items.title: China: Landslide Buries a Rural Village
items.abstract: A rescue operation was under way in a rural part of western China after a landslide buried a village in Yunnan Province, killing at least 42 people and injuring two others.

items.title: Charting a Post-Pollution Path for Cities – From London, 1952, through Beijing, 2013
items.abstract: Facing epic smog, China charts a shift from coal to gas for Beijing, and beyond.

items.title: Taliban Step Up Urban Assaults, Testing the Mettle of Afghan Forces
items.abstract: The government is trying to reassure citizens while the Taliban appears to be trying to strengthen its hand before peace talks.

items.title: Evictions in Walled Old City Stir Up a ‘Hornet’s Nest’
items.abstract: Palestinian residents of the Khaldiyya Ascent are facing eviction threats by Jewish organizations reclaiming properties they owned before Israel was established.

items.title: New York City to Get $176 Million From U.S. for Storm Protections
items.abstract: Senator Chuck Schumer said the city would be awarded federal funds for a proposed project to guard against another storm like Hurricane Sandy in Lower Manhattan.

items.title: How to Build Affordable Housing in New York City
items.abstract: Recent projects in which public housing was renovated by private developers could show a path forward.

items.title: National World War I Memorial Proposal Is Unveiled
items.abstract: A plan for a privately funded war memorial would create a raised lawn with a sculpture on a 1.8 acre site near the White House, not part of the National Mall.

items.title: Mexico City as the Director of ‘Roma’ Remembers It (and Hears It)
items.abstract: Alfonso Cuarón revisits the sights and sounds of the neighborhood that inspired his critically acclaimed film.

items.title: How Paparazzi Dogs and Rabbitgirl Conquered New York City Streets
items.abstract: Going around the traditional gatekeepers, Gillie and Marc Schattner of Australia have become the city’s most prolific creators of public art.

items.title: How Cities Make Money by Fining the Poor
items.abstract: In many parts of America, like Corinth, Miss., judges are locking up defendants who can’t pay — sometimes for months at a time.

items.title: Washington’s Strong Economy, Financed by Taxpayers, Takes Hit From Shutdown
items.abstract: As the country nears the end of its third week of a government shutdown, the nation’s capital has borne the brunt of its consequences.

items.title: Relief for New York City’s Transit Deserts? Commuter Trains Might Help
items.abstract: A planned billion-dollar rail expansion in the Bronx is fueling a larger debate over using aboveground trains to supplement subway and bus service.

items.title: Tianjin, a city of 14 million near Beijing, starts testing all residents after Omicron surfaces.
items.abstract: The city also announced a raft of restrictions in an effort to contain the outbreak and trace its source.

items.title: Breakouts and lockdowns in Chinese cities make a risk-free Olympics look unlikely.
items.abstract: Officials are racing to extinguish a spate of coronavirus infections around the country.

items.title: The Plans for the World’s Next Largest City Are Incomplete
items.abstract: Delhi is growing far beyond the formal confines of the city, a case study in the complexity of what we call urbanization.

items.title: ‘Now There Is No One’: The Lament of One of the Last Christians in a Syrian City
items.abstract: Michel Butros al-Jisri is among the few Christians left from a once-vibrant community in Idlib on the brink of disappearing. The city, in the only territory in Syria still controlled by rebels, is ruled by Islamists.

items.title: Taqueria Ramírez Brings a Mexico City Specialty to Brooklyn
items.abstract: A cut of beef little known in the United States emerges from a meat hot tub in Greenpoint to make a smooth, tender taco.
